definition[0]: a part of the US bankruptcy laws that allows a company with financial problems to reorganize itself so that it will not be forced to close down
example[0]: Our competitor has filed for Chapter 11.
definition[1]: part of the US law that deals with the process by which companies officially become bankrupt. Chapter 11 gives failing companies a period of time to reorganize, after which they must pay their creditors (=the people or companies they owe money to)
example[2]: The company said it filed for Chapter 11 protection (=asked for protection under Chapter 11) so it could fix financial and operational problems.
example[3]: MCI, formerly WorldCom, emerged from Chapter 11 in April 2004.
